article: A 10-year-old boy decided to study judo* although he had lost his left arm in a car accident. The boy began  _  with a Japanese judo coach. The boy was doing well, so he couldn't know  _  the coach taught him only one move. After three months of  _  , the boy finally asked, "Sir, should I start to learn more moves?" "This is the only move you know,  _  this is the only move you'll need to know," the coach replied. Not quite understanding, but the boy  believed in  his teacher. So he kept training. Several months  _  , the coach took the boy to his first match. To his surprise, the boy  _  won his first match. The second match was more difficult. But after some time, his opponent* became impatient. The boy used his one move to win the match again.  _  of the people in the stadium were amazed by his success. The boy was now in the finals. This time, his opponent was bigger,  _  , and more experienced. For a while, the boy seemed to  _  . Worried that the boy  _  get hurt, someone shouted, "Stop! Stop! Stop!" However, the coach said, "No,  _  ." As the match was keeping on, his opponent made a big mistake: he dropped his guard. Quickly, the boy used his move to  _  him. The boy won the final match. He was the winner.  _  the way home, the boy asked his coach: "Sir, how did I win the match with only one move?" "You won for  _  reasons," the coach answered, "First, you've almost known one of the most difficult moves in all of judo. And second, the only defense* for that move is for your opponent to catch your left arm." The boy's greatest weakness had become his greatest strength.
